history.content:
Depends hugely on how much a percentage your midterm is to the whole grade and how big your final is. If you do super well on the final, you can potentially reverse it all. I think it's still possible to walk away with an A- if you do really well.

Just so you know, my first semester at Cal, I took Math 53 with Givental :( and on my second midterm, I was one point from an F with the curve. The professor drew out the outline of grades and I was ultra devastated. I was the 4th lowest score on that midterm - two stds below average and one mercy point away from falling into the 3rd std away. I ultimately super studied my butt off for the final and ended up getting a B+ in the class. Its one of my saddest / happiest stories here at Cal, but I just wanted to show you that it's still possible. Don't give up buddy! You got this!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Couple of additions to the great response above:

(i) The composition of CS70 changes a lot when you move from Discrete Math to Probability, so if you are struggling with Discrete Math despite hard work, you may find solace in the fact that you could use Probability to balance things out (or vice versa)

(ii) Try looking into resources like CSM, HKN, etc; campus really tries to help students succeed, so don't fret just yet :

(iii) This being said, if you are L&S CS, it may be wise to keep your GPA declaration requirements in mind, as well as the new policies on grade replacements

(iv) A personal tip; I found the idea of webcasting 70 lecture at 2x the first time, then going through the notes, and then rewatching the parts I found confusing or difficult very effective as a way of getting the material; 70 is a very dense and challenging course (that moves very quickly as well), so don't be disheartened by initial failure, and keep trying :)

Best of luck!

children.subject: In my experience, I believe whatever the average is would usually be B. And 1 SD above/below is usually a A/C. If you are not very good at proofs/probability, you will have to be super determined to invest all the time that you have in this semester to focus on CS 70 MT2 and the final to reverse that. Good luck!
since many people with low score are dropping, it will cause the average even higher
omg does that mean if i'm .75 std below that i could go to d territory when a lot of people drop?

I wouldn't worry about that -- if this semester is like last semester, not too many people actually end up dropping:
https://www.berkeleytime.com/enrollment/?course1=2327-fall-2016-105588
not when the new declaration requirement is not imposed... i would not be surprised if people would drop and retake before the "F" is taken into consideration of the GPA requirement
Eh, that's true, but that's also balanced by the planned increase in the grade distribution.
under the new declaration requirement, I believe those who got at least 1 std below would drop to avoid getting a C or below
I got 1 std below and I am trying to drop the class and take it next semester
Usually the average is a B/B+ (after curve). 2 std below would definitely be C+/C. I would recommend dropping the course.
+1 Rao is an amazing professor. He really cares

I highly recommend reaching out to Professor Rao about your situation; I did poorly on the second midterm when I took the class in Spring of '16 and after meeting with him to go over my test and outline some study strategies/parts of the course I really needed to focus on, I ended up doing well enough on the final to pull an A- in the course. Rao is very approachable and genuinely wants to help you succeed, so I would definitely advise scheduling a meeting with him if you have the time.

history.content: Any idea of what my score after the curve will be? Also any advice in general for me? Thanks.
history.subject: Got 2 STDs below average on CS70 midterm.
